children.name: to show sb sth because you are proud of it
show off
children.definition: /ˌʃəʊ ˈɒf/  to show someone or something that you are proud of to other people:

children.name: show off something/somebody (to somebody)
examples: ▪ She raised her wrist, showing off a sparkling diamond bracelet.
▪ At last, this was a chance to show off her talents before a real audience.

children.name: show something/somebody off (to somebody)
examples: ▪ He wanted to show his daughter off to everybody.

children.name: flaunt
children.definition: /flɔːntǁflɔːnt, flɑːnt/  to let people see your valuable possessions so that they know you are rich or successful, in a way that annoys people:

children.name: ▪ Others have called him arrogant, for flaunting his millionaire lifestyle
examples: .▪ He’s very rich, but he doesn’t like to flaunt his wealth or waste his money.
▪ If you’ve got it, flaunt it!

children.name: flourish
children.definition: /ˈflʌrɪʃǁˈflɜːrɪʃ/  to wave something in your hand in order to make people notice it: ▪ She came in excitedly, flourishing a letter with her exam results.▪ The painting showed two gates guarded by imposing military figures flourishing swords.

children.name: parade
children.definition: /pəˈreɪd/  if someone parades another person, they show that person in public for others to see, usually proudly or as if they own them: parade across/through/beside etc
examples: ▪ The captured soldiers were paraded through the streets of the city.
▪ The senator loves parading his beautiful new wife before the nation.

children.name: to show sb a house, building, or place
show sb sth
children.definition: show somebody something/ˈʃəʊ somebody something/  to show someone a house, building, or other place by walking with them around it and telling them about it:
examples: ▪ Let me show you the garden.
▪ It’s worth asking a local guide to show you the sights.
▪ The real estate agent showed them house after house, but they couldn’t find one they liked.

children.name: show sb around
children.definition: show somebody aroundalso show somebody roundBritish /ˌʃəʊ somebody əˈraʊnd, ˌʃəʊ somebody ˈraʊnd/  to show someone the interesting or important parts of a place or building when they first visit it:
examples: ▪ She’d never been to Oxford before, so I offered to show her round.
▪ Later, he showed Margaret all around his new house.
▪ In the afternoon, we were shown around the Kennedy Space Center.

children.name: conduct
children.definition: /kənˈdʌkt/  to show someone a building or place on an official tour:
examples: ▪ An officer was sent to conduct the journalists around the shattered building. conducted tour [countable noun] an organized trip in which an official guide shows people a place:
▪ We went on a conducted tour of the castle.

children.name: conduct around
examples: ▪ The visitors were conducted around the factory by senior managers.

children.name: take sb on a tour
children.definition: take somebody on a tour/ˌteɪk somebody ɒn ə ˈtʊəʳ/  to show someone a city, museum, house etc, and tell them about all the important or interesting parts of it:
examples: ▪ Gregory took us on a riverboat tour down the Volga.
▪ Officials were taken on a tour of the one-time maximum security prison.

children.name: show
children.definition: /ʃəʊ/  to let someone see something, especially by holding it out in front of them:
examples: ▪ Everyone has to show their identity cards at the entrance to the building.

children.name: show somebody something
examples: ▪ Stephanie showed us her engagement ring.
▪ Show me what you’re hiding under the desk, Johnny.

children.name: show somebody something
examples: ▪ You have to show the security guard your pass.

children.name: show something to somebody
examples: ▪ Neil showed his Pokemon card collection to Harry.

children.name: let sb see
children.definition: let somebody see /ˌlet somebody ˈsiː/  especially spoken to show something to someone, especially because they have asked to see it:
examples: ▪ Could you let me see the menu?
▪ How would you feel if I wrote something about you, but I wouldn’t let you see it?
▪ Hold it up to the light and let me see what color it is.

children.name: let sb take a look
children.definition: let somebody take a lookalsolet somebody have a lookBritish /ˌlet somebody teɪk ə ˈlʊk, ˌlet somebody hæv ə ˈlʊk/  to show something to someone, especially so that they can look at it closely, for example in order to fix it:
examples: ▪ At least let Mike take a look -- he might be able to help.

children.name: let sb take a look at
examples: ▪ Let me have a look at your necklace. Perhaps I can fix it.
▪ Take your shirt off, and let me take a look at that cut on your shoulder.

children.name: present
children.definition: /prɪˈzent/  to show something such as an official document or ticket to someone in an official position:
examples: ▪ Please present your boarding card at the gate.

children.name: present something to somebody
examples: ▪ All passports must be presented to the immigration officer.

children.name: produce
children.definition: /prəˈdjuːsǁ-ˈduːs/  formal to take something such as a ticket or official paper out of your pocket or bag and show it to someone in an official position:
examples: ▪ The man fired from the car window when he was asked by a police officer to produce a license for the weapon.
▪ Failure to produce a valid insurance certificate may result in criminal prosecution.

children.name: flash
children.definition: /flæʃ/  to very quickly show something such as a ticket to someone when you are entering or leaving a place:
examples: ▪ He flashed his membership card as passed through the door.

children.name: flash something at somebody
examples: ▪ Two police officers burst in, the latter hurriedly flashing his ID card at her as they made their way upstairs.

children.name: expose
children.definition: /ɪkˈspəʊz/  formal to let someone see something that is usually covered or hidden:
examples: ▪ The animal opened its mouth, exposing rows of sharp white teeth.
▪ The receding tide had exposed huge expanses of sand.

children.name: reveal
children.definition: /rɪˈviːl/  to let someone see something that is usually hidden or that they did not know was there:
examples: ▪ She lifted the lid of the box to reveal a life-size porcelain baby doll.
▪ A medical examination may reveal evidence of dietary deficiencies.

children.name: to show sb where sth is
show
children.definition: /ʃəʊ/
examples: show (somebody) where
▪ The secretary showed him where to hang his coat.
▪ Please find enclosed a map showing where our offices areshow somebody something
▪ Uncle Joe showed me the best place to go fishing.show somebody the way
▪ I’ll show you the way to the station. It’s not far.

children.name: point to
children.definition: /ˈpɔɪnt tuː/  to show someone where someone or something is, by pointing towards it with your finger:
examples: ▪ He took out a map and pointed to the island.
▪ ‘The whiskey’s over there,’ Katie said, pointing to a bottle on the table.
▪ Can you point to the one you want?

children.name: point out
children.definition: /ˌpɔɪnt ˈaʊt/  to show someone a particular person or thing that you want them to notice, especially by pointing towards it with your finger:

children.name: point out somebody/something
examples: ▪ As we drove through Baltimore, Mary pointed out the house where she was born.

children.name: point somebody/something out
examples: ▪ Which one’s your boss? Can you point her out?

children.name: point out something to somebody
examples: ▪ ‘Aren’t they beautiful?’ said the guide, pointing out the paintings on the ceiling to us.

children.name: point out something for somebody
examples: ▪ Once they’d been pointed out for me, I had no trouble identifying the major stars and planets.

children.name: mark
children.definition: /mɑːʳk/  to show where something is by putting an object there or making a mark:
examples: ▪ Michael gave us a map of the city and marked some places of interest to visit.
▪ He put a slip of paper in his book to mark his page.
▪ A barbed wire fence marks the boundary between the two communities.

children.name: mark the spot
examples: ▪ The church marks the spot where St Peter died.

children.name: indicate
children.definition: /ˈɪndɪkeɪt, ˈɪndəkeɪt/  to show where something or someone is by pointing with part of your body:
examples: ▪ The Director indicated a small table, where the items were on display.
▪ ‘Shall we go in here?’ He indicated the coffee bar.

children.name: indicate (something) with something
examples: ▪‘That’s my boss,’ he said, indicating with a nod of his head.

name: to show/be a sign of sth

children.name: to show that sb or sth is bad
show
children.definition: /ʃəʊ/
examples: ▪ His approach to the problem showed a complete lack of understanding.

children.name: show how/what/why etc
examples: ▪ This just shows how the standard of reporting has declined over the past ten years.
▪ Maddie’s remarks showed why she is disliked and feared by her fellow workers.

children.name: not say much for
children.definition: alsonot say a lot for somebody/something/nɒt seɪ ˈmʌtʃ fɔːʳ, nɒt seɪ ə ˈlɒt fɔːʳ somebody/something ǁ-ˈlɑːt-/  if a fact or achievement does not say much for someone or something, it shows very clearly that they are not as good, skilful etc as they should be:
examples: ▪ Only a quarter of the class passed the exam, which doesn’t say much for the quality of the teaching.
▪ It doesn’t say much for the media that they are criticizing something they haven’t even seen yet.

children.name: be a reflection on
children.definition: /biː ə rɪˈflekʃən ɒn/  if a bad situation or a bad result is a reflection on someone or something, it shows their character, abilities, or qualities are not very good, because the bad situation or result is their fault:

children.name: ▪ ‘It’s no reflection on you,’ Fred explained kindly. ‘My mum’s always like that with my girlfriends.’
examples: ▪ When children are criticized, mothers often see it as a reflection on themselves.

children.name: reflect badly on
children.definition: alsonot reflect well on somebody/something/rɪˌflekt ˈbædli ɒn, nɒt rɪˌflekt ˈwel ɒn somebody/something/  if an action or event reflects badly on someone, it shows that they have bad qualities, and this makes people’s opinion of them become worse:
examples: ▪ The way that the refugees have been treated reflects very badly on the government.

children.name: ▪ Both women knew that squabbling in public would reflect badly on both of them
be a comment on
children.definition: /biː ə ˈkɒment ɒnǁ-ˈkɑː-/  if a bad situation is a comment on problems or changes that affect all of society, it shows that these problems or changes exist and have a bad influence:
examples: ▪ The increasing focus on sex and violence in most movies is a comment on the changing tastes of the movie-going public.

children.name: be a sad/damning comment on
examples: ▪ The food queues were a sad comment on the quality of life in the new republic.
▪ To suggest that people are only honest when it can benefit them, is a damning comment on the human character.

children.name: be symptomatic of
children.definition: also be a symptom of /biː ˌsɪmptəˈmætɪk ɒv, biː ə ˈsɪmptəm ɒv/  formal if a small problem is symptomatic of a more serious or general problem, it shows that the more serious or general problem exists:
examples: ▪ The whole episode was symptomatic of the US determination to avoid another Cuba.
▪ Noisy classrooms are a symptom of a breakdown in authority.

children.name: be an indictment of
children.definition: /biː ən ɪnˈdaɪtmənt ɒv/  to show very clearly that a system, plan etc is very bad, very wrong, or is not working in the way that it should:
examples: ▪ The movie is neither an indictment nor an endorsement of capital punishment.

children.name: be a glaring/sad/serious etcindictment of something be a very clear sign of something bad
examples: ▪ Numbers of casualties among refugees represent an appalling indictment of Western policy.
▪ It is a serious indictment of a medical profession so arrogant that it dismisses out of hand any ‘alternative’ forms of therapy.

children.name: make a mockery of
children.definition: /ˌmeɪk ə ˈmɒkəri ɒvǁ-ˈmɑːk-/  to show that something such as a system, principle, or idea is completely false, stupid, or ineffective - use this especially when you think it is wrong that something should be made to seem bad or wrong :
examples: ▪ If that man gets released, it will make a mockery of our legal system.
▪ Recent expenditure on defense has made a mockery of government promises to improve the lives of ordinary Russians.

children.name: when sth shows that sth else is likely to be true
suggest
children.definition: /səˈdʒestǁsəg-/  to show that something is probably true, even though there is no definite proof:
examples: ▪ In fact, the situation is far worse than these figures suggest.
suggest (that)
▪ There was nothing in his letter to suggest that he might have been unhappy or depressed.
▪ The drop in trading suggests the Asian economies may be headed for recession.suggest something to somebody
▪ A child’s behavior might suggest to others that there are problems at home.strongly suggest show that something is very likely
▪ The door had not been forced open, which strongly suggests that the victim was known to her killer.

children.name: indicate
children.definition: /ˈɪndɪkeɪt, ˈɪndəkeɪt/  if scientific facts, tests, official figures etc indicate something, they show that it is likely to be true:
examples: ▪ How badly reform is needed was indicated recently by the rising youth crime figures.

children.name: indicate (that)
examples: ▪ Research indicates that the drug can be harmful to pregnant women.
▪ Campaign finance records indicate many of the guests were donors to his own party.

children.name: give the impression
children.definition: /ˌgɪv ði ɪmˈpreʃən/  to make people think that a particular situation exists, even though this may not actually be true:
examples: ▪ She wasn’t stupid, though at times she gave that impression.
give the impression (that)
▪ The luxurious offices gave the impression that the company had plenty of money to spare.
give the impression of
▪ All this splendour and ceremony may at first give the impression of high culture and sophistication.give the impression that

children.name: point to
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: /ˈpɔɪnt tuː/  to show that a particular explanation for something is likely to be true or that something is likely to happen in the future:
examples: ▪ All the evidence points to a fatty diet being the main cause of heart disease in the West.
▪ The poor economic climate and the attitude of leading executives both point to a grim future.

children.name: imply
children.definition: /ɪmˈplaɪ/  if a fact or piece of information, especially scientific information, implies something, it shows that it is likely to be true:
examples: ▪ Among the ruins there are inscriptions, implying some degree of literacy even in the 9th century BC.
▪ As the examples imply, some markets are local while others are national or international in scope
.imply (that)
▪ The results imply that the disease originated in West Africa.

children.name: implicate
children.definition: /ˈɪmplɪkeɪt, ˈɪmpləkeɪt/  to show that someone or something is likely to be involved in or connected to something, especially something bad or harmful:

children.name: ▪ According to the prosecution, DNA tests ‘irrefutably’ implicate Henson.implicate in
examples: ▪ Sexually transmitted diseases have long been implicated in infertility.

children.name: implicate as
examples: ▪ Seafood is increasingly implicated as the source of the hepatitis A virus.

children.name: mplicate himself/yourself etc show, suggest, or prove that he etc has committed a crime
examples: ▪ Simon knew he couldn’t possibly provide a blood sample without implicating himself.

children.name: be indicative of
children.definition: /biː ɪnˈdɪkətɪv əv something/  formal if something is indicative of an event or situation, it shows that the event or situation is likely to exist or be true, but it is not definite that it does
examples: : ▪ Persistent abdominal pain may be indicative of appendicitis.
▪ The absence of any famous female composers is more indicative of male dominance than male genius.

children.name: to show that sth is going to happen
mean
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: /miːn/  to be a sign that something is very likely to happen:
examples: ▪ Dark clouds usually mean rain.

children.name: mean (that)
examples: ▪ High interest rates and high inflation mean a recession is not far away.
▪ His new responsibilities at work mean Leroy will rarely see his children.

children.name: take something to mean (that)believe that something is a sign of something
examples: ▪ Stein took off his glasses and rested his head on the back of the chair. I took this to mean that he wasn’t going to say any more.

children.name: spell
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: /spel/  if a situation or action spells trouble, problems etc, it makes you expect that something bad will happen, because there are clear signs that it will:
examples: ▪ No one thinks this could spell the closure of the firm, but things could be better.
▪ Out-of-town retail developments often spell the death of independent high street shops.

children.name: bode well/ill
children.definition: /ˌbəʊd ˈwel, ˈɪl/  formal to be a sign that something good or bad is likely to happen in the future:
examples: ▪ Gandalf’s late arrival did not bode well
.bode well/ill for
▪ The drop in profits bodes ill for Japan’s semiconductor industry.
▪ The high early viewing figures bode well for writers Lane and Harvey, who hope to achieve network success.

children.name: herald
children.definition: /ˈherəld/  to be a sign that something is going to happen soon, especially something important - used especially in literature or newspapers:

children.name: ▪ In February, the first storks arrive, heralding spring
examples: .▪ What changes do the attacks herald for everyday life in the US?
▪ His prosecution perhaps heralds an end to the systematic corruption that has stained this government’s reputation.

children.name: herald something as
examples: ▪ Taxol has been heralded as a breakthrough in cancer treatment.

children.name: when sth shows that sth else is true
show
children.definition: /ʃəʊ/  to prove that something is true:
examples: ▪ Her nervousness is shown by a tendency to laugh a lot in public.
show (somebody) how/what/why etc
▪ It cost $5000 to repair the car -- that shows how bad the damage was!
▪ It shows you what they think of their customers, if they can’t even be bothered to answer your letter!
show something/somebody to dosomething
▪ Caffeine has been shown to have a good effect on mental performance
.show (that)
▪ The evidence shows that this area was probably the site of a Roman settlement
.▪ The polls clearly show that the voters are dissatisfied with the present government.it (just) goes to show use to emphasize that something proves that what you are saying is true
▪ It just goes to show that we can all learn from experience, whether we’re 8 or 80.

children.name: be a sign
children.definition: /biː ə ˈsaɪn/  if an event or action is a sign of something else, it is one of the things that shows that something is probably true:

children.name: be a sign of
examples: ▪ The public opposition to the airport is a sign of how much people’s attitudes have changed.
▪ A cluttered desk is a sign of a creative mind.

children.name: be a sign that
examples: ▪ When a dog wags his tail, it’s a sign that he’s happy.

children.name: be a sure/clear sign
examples: ▪ My mother pursed her lips, a sure sign of displeasure.

children.name: take/view/see somethingas a sign that decide that it shows something
examples: ▪ When she didn’t return my calls, I took it as a sign that she just wasn’t interested.

children.name: demonstrate
children.definition: /ˈdemənstreɪt/  formal to show very clearly that something is true - use this especially in official or technical contexts:

children.name: ▪ His commitment to the company is demonstrated by his work on the project.demonstrate how/why/whether etc
examples: ▪ Here are some examples that demonstrate how badly some students write their resumés.
▪ The assessment center gives each applicant the opportunity to demonstrate whether they are suited to the work.

children.name: demonstrate that
examples: ▪ I’m afraid this whole episode demonstrates that we have become less compassionate as a society.

children.name: demonstrate (something) to somebody
examples: ▪ You’ve got to be able to demonstrate to people that the union can help in these cases.

children.name: mean
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: /miːn/  if an event or action means something, you can guess from it that something has happened or is true:
examples: ▪ Cloudy water from the taps usually means problems with your storage tank.
▪ A free economy does not mean the absence of any economic control.

children.name: mean (that)
examples: ▪ This sort of behaviour means that the child is definitely unhappy.
▪ If A is false, does that also mean proposition B is false?

children.name: must mean
examples: ▪ Her car’s not there, so that must mean she’s gone to pick him up.

children.name: make clear
children.definition: /ˌmeɪk ˈklɪəʳ/  to show very clearly that something is true: make it clear (that)
examples: ▪ This new evidence makes it clear that Rourke was acting independently of the others.
make it clear what/why/how etc
▪ The look in her eyes made it clear what she meant.make clear something
▪ The Unabomber’s diary makes clear his loathing and contempt for society.

children.name: reflect
children.definition: /rɪˈflekt/  if something reflects a situation or fact, it is a result of that situation or fact and shows clearly that the situation or fact exists:
examples: ▪ The three-year guarantee reflects the company’s confidence in the quality of its products.
▪ His fair, freckled skin and blue eyes reflect his Irish heritage.
▪ This poll reflects what the Republicans of California are sensing
.be reflected in
▪ The culture of a nation is always reflected in its language.

children.name: illustrate
children.definition: /ˈɪləstreɪt/  to be an example which shows that a fact is true or that a situation exists:
examples: ▪ As this story illustrates, some stars have become as bored as audiences by Hollywood extravagance.
▪ This point can be illustrated by two brief examples.

children.name: illustrate how/why/what
examples: ▪ The experiment illustrates how careful you have to be when interpreting results.

children.name: tell
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: /tel/  if a situation, detail etc tells you something, it helps you to know, understand, or guess more about something:
examples: ▪ What does this tell us about the experience of young immigrants to this country?

children.name: tell somebody how many/much etc
examples: ▪ Unfortunately, the photographs can tell us very little about the potential for life on Mars.

children.name: tell somebody that
examples: ▪ The research told us that many drug addicts were returning to heroin up to three years after the treatment.

children.name: be evidence
children.definition: /biː ˈevdəns/  if a situation, detail, fact is evidence of a general situation, attitude, type of behaviour etc, it shows that it exists:

children.name: be evidence of
examples: ▪ Changes in sexual laws in recent years are evidence of a gradual movement towards greater tolerance.

children.name: be evidence that
examples: ▪ Journalists argue that being attacked by both sides is evidence that their coverage is fair.
▪ This is clear evidence that the crime figures do not represent the true situation.

children.name: reveal
children.definition: /rɪˈviːl/  to show something that most people did not know or realize is true:
examples: ▪ The way he spoke in the bar afterwards revealed prejudice and bitterness that I had never suspected.
▪ Separate holidays and weekends apart reveal more clearly than any words the state of their marriage.
reveal how/why/what etc
▪ The President’s refusal to meet the press reveals just how serious the crisis is.
▪ Positive tests have revealed why some athletes were so reluctant to co-operate.reveal that
▪ The fact that there are no black officers in the entire regiment reveals that the army is not serious about its anti-discrimination policies.
revealing [adjective]
▪ a very revealing statement

children.name: to show that sb or sth is good
show
children.definition: /ʃəʊ/
examples: ▪ His performance shows great talent.
▪ Lieutenant Marche’s actions showed great courage and leadership.

children.name: show how/what/why etc
examples: ▪ This latest album certainly shows why Pine is rated a first-class jazz musician among his peers.

children.name: say a lot for/about
children.definition: alsosay a great deal for/about/ˌseɪ ə ˈlɒt fɔːʳ, əbaʊtǁ-ˈlɑːt-, ˌseɪ ə greɪt ˈdiːl fɔːʳ, əbaʊt/  informal to show very clearly that someone has good qualities, though those qualities are not always named:
examples: ▪ The decision says a great deal for Chang’s courage and convictions.
▪ To have those sort of setbacks and still keep everything together says a lot about Richard.

children.name: say a lot for/about tha
examples: t▪ It says a lot for Banks that he decided to finish the race even though he had no hope of winning.

children.name: be a tribute to
children.definition: /biː ə ˈtrɪbjuːt tuː/  if a fact or achievement is a tribute to someone or something, it shows their good qualities because it is a result of those qualities:
examples: ▪ It was a tribute to her teaching methods that most of the children passed the tests.
▪ That the book was ever finished was a tribute to the patience and dedication of all concerned.

children.name: reflect well on
children.definition: /rɪˌflekt ˈwel ɒn/  if an action or event reflects well on a person or organization, it shows that they have good qualities or abilities, and this makes people’s opinion of them improve:
examples: ▪ Military success always reflects well on the government in power at the time.
▪ This win reflects well on the growing strength of our young players.
▪ The television coverage of the trial reflected well on NBC.

children.name: be a testament to
children.definition: /biː ə ˈtestmənt tuː/  formal if something is testament to a particular quality or person, it shows how good, strong, skilled etc that quality or person really is:

children.name: ▪ The incredible precision of the equipment is testament to the mechanical skill of the engineers who built it
examples: .▪ It is a testament to the greatness of Rodgers & Hart that their music still sounds as fresh and vital as the day it was written.
